description.text:
I'm proving a point.  
perfectly 40mm in diameter with 1mm thick walls.
A simple frame to prevent damage to the Bitcraze Crazyflie.

v1.7 - See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:90566 v1.6.5 - This frame is similar to v1.5 with some minor alterations to the motor attachments and thicker/stronger outer rings.
Attach frame to the bottom side of the plastic motor mounts of the Bitcraze Crazyflie quad and fix with foam tape (carefull do not to clip the motor wires). Fix battery between the underside of the quad board and the frame and fix with tape when quad is balanced.
The battery on the underside of the quad allows for greater stability. v1.5 - Attach to the bottom side of the plastic motor mounts of the Bitcraze Crazyflie quad (carefull do not to clip the motor wires). Fix battery between the underside of the quad board and the frame and fix with tape when quad is balanced.
The battery on the underside of the quad allows for greater stability. v1.2 - Attach to the top flat side of the plastic motor mounts of the Bitcraze Crazyflie quad using simple or two sided adhesive tape. Attach the battery to the frame and have fun. Print with flex PLA or nylon preferably. Enjoy.

remixed_from.author: Rhuuk
remixed_from.title: 40mm kossel delta rostock E3D v6 metal effector.

description.text:
This is a v1 of the Diamond Nozzle refitted for a delta printer, using my 40mm effector. there are a couple of reasons for the effector arm connections being so low on the part:
  • delta printers tend to like a low center of gravity. putting the arm braces up towards the top would have made the entire effector act abit like a pendulum.
  • the arms need a certain amount of space so that you can actually run the m3 screws through it. this was about as close to the bottom as I could get, and still imagie clearance for the 3 hotends assembled on top of it. still, the tolerances are going to be tight for mounting m3 bolts with m3 nuts. you may have to turn to reversing flat heads to go from the inside out.
  • looking at the fan positioning, it would interfere with the arms at the outer edges, compromising you ability to maximize your real estate on your print bed. moving them closer to the base hopefully moves the bulk up above the arms and gives enough clearance for the entire head.
    • this was mounted in such a way that each hot end would feed up towards an arm, so as to make mounting, bowden runs and tie-down's simpler and aligned with each arm. this hasn't been proven yet with an actual diamond head nozzle, so if anyone print one and assemble it for proofs, please let me know if you do and any adjustments that need to be made.

used sketchup to clean the 1st part and remove the side bracket.
used 123d to merge the 2 parts and cut out the difference using the metal nozzle model.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3tUFVsAHASf

I bought myself a FlashForge Dreamer as a spare printer, and I rather like it, except for the fact that it's designed for use with small internal filament spools.  I have a bunch of colors of filament in larger spools. My solution to that is to drill two holes in the back edge of the lid, add a couple 6-inch Bowden-like tubes to guide filament from two spool holders on the back of the printer.  
This design is one of those spool holders.  
If printed in ABS, you can use Acetone to solvent-glue the holders onto the back of the ABS case permanently.  
This should also work great for the Dremel 3D Idea Builder (which is a re-branded FlashForge Dreamer, with one extruder instead of dual extruders.)

Print with high infill density. Printing in ABS is recommended, but not required. If you need to tweak the sizes for this design:
  • Unpack the .zip file.
  • Edit the .scad file to tweak the parameters.
  • Open the .scad file with OpenSCAD.
  • Select Render from the Design menu.
  • Select "Export as STL..." from the File->Export menu.
  • Save the STL file.
  • Slice the STL file.
  • Print.

author: tuxcat

title: CubixLED - an LED matrix frame project

description.text:
Created this for a large scale RGB 8x8 matrix project, I've also included smaller 4x4 versions to fit other printers. There are two versions of each size, one for 5mm round LEDs and the other for 5050 style square LEDs found on flexible strips.  
This will be used with some individually addressable RGB LED strips (generic Digital Dream variants found on Amazon) cut down and mounted on the back. I have some frosted lighting film for the front (Roscolux 116) that will be attached with VHB double sided tape. Since the strips were about $12 per meter I can build each matrix for about $20, far less than what comparable 8x8 matrix panels I've found. Controller will likely be a Teensy 3.1, since the strips are designed to be connected end to end it should allow me to control a bunch of these panels with one device.  
I'll refresh this with photos as the project progresses. Enjoy!  
Single cell and 8x8 SCAD files created. First time using OpenSCAD so maker beware!
UPDATE: Added new version that should match most 60 LEDs per meter strips (16.667mm apart). Requires far less cutting and soldering, thickness reduced to 12.7mm. Strips can be secured directly to the back, this will allow you to build edge-to-edge matrix displays with 8 running strips.

comments.text: SCAD files for a single cell and an 8x8 5mm LED form created. It was my first attempt at using OpenSCAD, let me know if it works for you.

comments.text: Take it off. Subarus are incredibly finicky when it comes to engine management, especially when dealing with air intake. Any changes to the intake side of things typically requires a tune. Since this device repositions the flow sensor, it is getting unexpected values. Unexpected values result in codes being thrown, which often results in the ECU nerfing your car.

This is an electronics enclosure designed for a MakerGear M2 retrofitted with a Smoothieboard controller.  Features include a snap-on lid that releases easily by pushing the latches on the side;  ample cut-outs for air flow, cut-outs for the USB and ethernet ports, and the microSD card, and even a hole in the lid for access to the reset button using a small allen wrench.

Full instructions on how to retrofit a MakerGear M2 with a Smoothieboard controller are posted on the MakerGear forum site at http://forum.makergear.com/viewtopic.php?f=10&t=2248. Whether you would actually want to retrofit an M2 with a Smoothieboard is all part of the discussion. However, for anyone who decides to do so, this enclosure is a perfect fit for both the M2 and the controller board. The box rests on the bottom of the frame and attaches to the side with the two existing screws used for the RAMBo controller. The fan screws to the lid, also with existing hardware. The Smoothieboard sits snugly on internal ledges and posts and does not need to be screwed down. Although there are a few overhangs in the design, it should print without needing support. I printed mine in eSUN black PETg from Intservo; you can't go wrong with that choice! The best approach is to print the box first, then mount it on the M2; and based on how all the wires are arranged, choose the best position for the fan so that it is in a relatively uncluttered spot, where wires won't be pushing up against it. Then edit the openSCAD source for the lid and change the fan X and Y positions accordingly.

comments.text: How does the smoothieboard compare to the RAMBo board print quality wise?
comments.author: mharter

comments.text: The quality is largely a function of the machine's hardware, not the firmware.  The smoothieboard can get the same print quality at a bit higher speed, maybe 30% or so, due to the faster clock rate of the microprocessor;  it can look further ahead for path planning.
comments.author: mharter

I created this battery holder since i just got a battery powered lawnmower and wanted to hang my batteries. I didn't see any holders so I designed this one. It works with my 2 Ah (29141, 40V DC 73Wh { http://www.craftsman.com/craftsman-40v-lithium-ion-battery/p-07198740000P }) and my 4 Ah (138.98742, 40V DC 146Wh { http://www.sears.com/craftsman-40v-rechargeable-lithium-ion-battery-98742/p-07198742000P }) batteries.

I recommend printing this solid (90% fill).  I hollowed out the bottom to save material and ta make printing with 90% fill feasible.  You can print with light supports (I did) and it took about 12 m of my 1.75mm filament.

comments.text: It seems like you could print this standing up and use no supports. Then you wouldn't have to clean out the tracks that hold the battery, and you would be gaining strength along the tracks because each layer would be a continuous band to hold the battery, instead of forming fault lines at the thin sections.
comments.author: rundmcarlson

comments.text: You are probably right about printing this standing.  I don't need anymore so I won't be printing any to confirm.  Thanks for the feedback.

title: MTG - Magic the Gathering 75 Card Box and Magic the Gathering 100 Card Sleeved Box

description.text:
This is a Card box i modeled, the magic card is printed twice and super glued to the front and back.  I used raw filament as pegs for the hinges and then melted the ends down a little which allows it to stay in place.  
Also i have 1/16 IN diameter holes on the corners of the top and bottom pieces so magnets can be place there, though with the tight hinges, the lid stays closed on its own pretty good.  
The spine has 2 divots for 2 D20 dice, you can then use the lid for your Library and the box for your graveyard or vs versa.  
I am working another version for 100+ cards with additional features, but i wanted to get this model shared first ;)

comments.text: Little to No supports should be required, i print my pieces out without them.  Spine i had stand upright, main box i had laid down on the back, and the the cards that go on the front and back i had upright but i did have a raft to keep them in place, that be only piece to have a support on.

comments.text: I tried printing this out and it looks really nice! I love the design. But maybe I did something wrong because the pieces don't really fit together as expected. The top has a bevel which prevents it from sealing to the box. The hinges on the spine don't seem to fit into the top or the box hinges correctly. It looks like the rounded cutouts near the hinges on the top and box parts are too shallow and not fully cut out. I also noticed that the commander box isn't deep enough for the 100 cards in sleeves. However, the box is a bit wider than expected and there is about 3-4mm of space all around the perimeter of the sleeved cards. Maybe its because the sleeves I'm using are thicker and shorter than the ones you used? Maybe it has to do with the 1.75 filament I'm using? Anyways, have these sorts of issues come up before? Might try my hand at adjusting the dimensions of the parts myself. If all else fails I'll just take a dremel to it and use it as a nice dice box :)

title: DreamCatcher 06 - micro quad frame for 6mm motors

description.text:
This is the 6mm DreamCatcher.
Flies like a Ninja, crashes like a Boss! If you want the toughest and sexiest DreamCatcher possible, CNC master Woodsturning got you covered. Grab one here: http://micro-motor-warehouse.com/collections/dreamcatchers

comments.text:
Im flying this with eachine h8 mini electronics. So funny!
I have one question though: How can I prevent the motor wires from tearing apart? This happens way too often. Or are there other 6mm motors with stronger cables?
comments.author: MaximilianRainer

comments.text:
I like to use screw thread protectors, basically small rubber cups.
Google "1/4" Screw Thread Covers" and you should find some that fit 6mm motors.
comments.author: MaximilianRainer

comments.text: I have put a little bit of glue onto the underside of the motors, the cables don't break there anymore, but the cables break between the motors and the fc if I for example crash into a wall and one of the motors comes out of his mount (GREAT design, i haven't yet broken a prop on this frame) the wires tear apart...
comments.author: MicroMotorWarehouse

comments.text: I am on my second print of this frame.  The first one didn't hold the motors very tightly, and they would pop out very easily.  Also, just using the quad would cause them to turn in the frame, and if I didn't check frequently they would wind up.  The H8 Mini has very short wires that lose length quickly when it starts winding up.  If you don't kill the power immediately after a crash it is possible that the motor itself is tearing the wires apart.

title: Lead-screw mount for a sliding window

description.text: I'm using this for a project on hackaday.io, a weather controlled SmartWindow, listed here: https://hackaday.io/project/4789-weather-controlled-smartwindow As such, it's very specific to my application, but I've made it available to all. At the default scaling, it should fit a 3/8" screw diameter, though your tolerance may vary, based on print quality. It also includes two hex-nut bracket holds to minimize stress on the printed part.

Should print easily on most machines with tolerance < 1mm. My successful prototype was made on a Makerbot Replicator (1st gen), on medium quality via MakerWare. I recommend not using support, as the small cavities may be difficult to clear out, if unnecessary internal supports are created.

Making a file such as this will make it easier to find the size of slots in your press fit structures.
This file was designed in Inkscape. You could use another application, such as Open Office, Cut Studio or similar to serve the same purposes of determining the correct size for your slots on a given material cut on the laser cutter.

Use this file to find your slot sizes.
Send this to the laser cutter.
The square shape will be represent the tabs
The rectangles will be the slots.
You need to know the height of the slots and the width of the slots.
After cutting the file in the material you will be using, use the square to test the fit of the slots.
When you find the best height and width of the slots, you will use those dimensions for the slots on your press fit structure. If you don't find a fit that works with the first set of dimensions, use the best fit and make another set of slots.

The headline is "My Replicator and Nylon printing saved me $800".  
I've been using my Replicator to print replacement parts for my dishwasher, because the parts companies only sell the complete rack assembly, for $400/rack . I originally printed them in ABS, but after a few months the ABS breaks down under the heat and stress of the interior of a dishwasher. Rather than print replacements every few months, I was about to break down and buy the (expensive) replacement assemblies, when Taulman 645 came out. Like Taulman 618, it's Nylon, which is (nearly) indestructible, but 645 is much more rigid than 618, so it works very nicely for this application. So rather than spending $800 on replacement assemblies, I've been printing them again in Taulman 645 Nylon. Yay!  
The parts are all generated in OpenSCAD, so you can customize them to the measurements of your dishwasher.  In particular, pin size, length, and spacing are highly variable between dishwashers.  
Part 1: This is my unimaginative name for a rack section that folds up and down, on the top rack. The printed one isn't as strong as the metal piece it replaced, but it's sufficient to hold glasses in place so they don't hit each other. The pin spacing is uneven, because I copied the original part.  
Part 2: This is a clip that holds a cross-piece in place. The cross-piece rotates so that pins are either up or down. I designed the piece so that the identical part works on both ends of the cross-piece.   
Rack Protector: Pins tend to rust at the joint where they attack to the rack. This protector is a piece that fits over the pins in the rack to protect the joint where the pin attaches to the rack. This strengthens the joint if it's already weakened, and it protects it from damage, because dishes rest on the protector instead of the (thin) plastic coating on the pin.  These snap nicely into place, so you don't need any adhesive to hold them in place.  This is Ed Nisley's Dishwasher Rack Protector, tweaked a bit.  
Rack Protector with Pin: if the pin has broken off, you can use a protector which includes the pin, in place of the missing pin. You'll need to glue the base into place so that it doesn't swivel around the rack.  There's a parameter in the code so that if there's a 'stub' of the pin left, this will fit over the stub.  This is from my Rack Protector with Pin.   
I'm including the STL files, and a few photos, so that you can see what the parts are. But it's highly unlikely that the parts that fit my KitchenAid dishwasher will fit your dishwasher, so you'll likely need to take some measurements and tweak the OpenSCAD files to fit your needs.   
I hope these are useful!

Printed using Taulman 645 Nylon, at 240 degrees, 40 mm/s, 0.4mm layer height. Printed on Garolite LE heated to 110 degrees. 3 shells, 20% infill. Worked great for all parts.  
Also printed using Taulman 618 Nylon, at 240 degrees, 40 mm/s, 0.27mm layer height. Printed on Garolite LE, unheated. 3 shells, 20% infil. Worked great for the protectors.  
What you should do is measure the part that needs replacing in your dishwasher, and tweak the OpenSCAD to suit. The important thing is to copy the relevant structural elements, not every detail of the part. I found that all of the parts that I designed to be 3D printable turned out quite functional, but they look very different from the injection molded or mass-produced parts that they replaced.

title: Office chair pneumatic cylinder fix clip

description.text:
This spacer clip stops your office chair from sinking, when the pneumatic cylinder is broken.  
2015-05-25 - Added ChairFix2.scad which has a secondary clip to stop it popping off, if your chair like mine, has a slightly conical outer piston.

Resize the scad to fit, or print multiples of the STLs.  
Printed in ABS. To give it some extra spring I did 100% fill, fill pattern concentric in the middle and rectilinear top/bottom. With slic3r v1.2.6 the concentric pattern left a little gap in the middle, which I think may have helped give it some extra spring. It went on with a lovely snap and there are no strain marks on the plastic.

description.text: This part is part of the Open Algae Farm project which you can find out more about here: http://openalgaefarm.netai.net/ . This part is designed to link 5/8" vinyl tubing together for the purpose of farming algae for biofuel

This part was printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal. A few things to note for printing is that the part won't be waterproof so it must be dipped in primer (it works really well). The part should also be scaled up based on the flexibility of your tubing.

title: Ryobi One+ battery connector + other pieces to make a powerful LED lamp.

description.text: This is a remix of the Ryobi battery holder by MichaelAtOz (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82868). This is modified to hold a powerful 50 W LED powered by a DC-DC Boost Converter (but I am running it at 20 W since at 50 W the heat sink gets too hot). See instructions for more details.

1) Printed in PLA, 20% infill. The largest piece may be tricky to print due to a large bridged area. Printed OK without support on my printrbot simple 1405. 2) I had to scale MichaelAtOz design by 95% and had to add thinner and higher plastic tabs to the holder for the battery clips I used which must be assembled higher than Michael's (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00SRRZ5MQ/). 3) Parts are screwed together and I also added some adhesive between the parts when possible. 4) Print 3 "cylinders" and drive them through the large holes in the main part to help support the holder against the battery (less wobble). 5) I used a simple metallic hinge to attach the heatsink for the LED. 6) The LED is a 50 W Led (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00D1GT772/), but I am running it at only 20 W (plenty bright). 7) The LED requires above 30 V, I used a DC-DC boost converter (www.amazon.com/DROK-Constant-Current-Converter-Regulated/dp/B00COX3VZ2/). 8) The "shade" was printed in florescent PLA, after the LED is turned off it remains a cool green (see photo).

comments.text: Really cool ! What kind of LED driver did you use ?
comments.author: Sm3cK

comments.text: In the instructions:  The LED requires above 30 V, I used a DC-DC boost converter (www.amazon.com/DROK-Constant-Current-Converter-Regulated/dp/B00COX3VZ2/). Forgot to mention that this converter allows to fix both max. voltage and current.  I have set the maximum voltage to 35 V, and adjust the current to the desired power (you have to check V*I as you lower the current).

title: Spinner for Infield Engineering 45" Miles M.20 Pocket Fighter

description.text:
This spinner fits the 45" radio controlled Miles M.20 model of my design. This model was released as a free digital plan in the July 2015 issue of Model Aviation magazine. This is a 2-piece assembly. The nose cone snaps into the backing plate. The cone's OD is 82mm. The length is 64mm. This spinner works well with an eFlite 4mm prop adapter.   
NOTE:  the spinner plate has been improved by adding two thin cylinders to the propellor hub pocket.  These cylinders make the part easier to print.  Break them both out and clean up the pocket area before use.
Follow the AMA Safety Code when using this part!  Propellors and spinners that rotate at high speed are inherently dangerous.  Use extreme care in fabricating and using this part.  Use at your own risk!

Three files are offered for this Thing. Files 2 and 3 are for makers having trouble building the two parts from a single file.

  • Spinner 3--contains the spinner cap and the backing plate in a single file.

  • Spinner Cap--contains just the cone of the spinner that snaps into the Plate

  • Spinner Plate--contains the backing plate

author: lescoste

description.text:
An angled foregrip that attaches to any picatinny/1913 rail.  Works for air soft, bb guns or the real scary black ones.  I added a curved version so you can pick whichever you like better.   
Edit:  Curved version with the grip 1" wide is added.
Edit 2:  Added a step file of just the base if you want to design off of it.

Print with ABS at 1:1 scale.  I used 30% infill with it fully supported.  Printing it on its side with support seems to work better for the finger serrations.  The clamp section is 3" long with clearance for two 8-32 x 1.25" SHCS with 8-32 nuts to clamp it to a picatinny.  The grip is on a 20° slant and it is about 4-5/8" x 2-1/2" x 1-3/8 at the rail clamp (3/4" wide on the grip).  The length on the grip is 3-1/2" between stops with a boss in the center.

description.text: It's a working wing, or normally it should, designed in blender. You can stretch it to your needs with free software from blender.org.

Building this simple wing is easy. Scale it on your needs in blender (1 unit = 1mm), with the scale 's' button, selecting the axis with 'x', 'y' or 'z'. Then move mouse or type number for scaling.
Then use export -> stl and send to your mendel/ultimaker alike :D
Don't forget to drill holes in it ;) Have fun flying!

description.text:
I don't know about you but 99% of the time when someone finds out I have a 3D printer the first thing most people say is 'can you print me a gun?'.  No, that's illegal and, frankly, insulting to something which can do so much more and bring such creativity to life.   
Therefore I present to you a token to give to these people when they ask that question, if you even want to waste filament on that sort of thing...

comments.text:
Here was my answer to the annoyingly common question, "have you printed a gun?": http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162118
BTW, I can happily report that I get asked this question a lot less over the past year.

remixed_from.author: pLaStIc sPiDeR for ZMR-250 Quad Copter
remixed_from.title: Original Uni-Spacer V2

remixed_from.author: scoopdreams
remixed_from.title: KISS ESC tray and guard for ZMR250 or other quad

description.text:
This Thing is a work in progress. A Uni-Spacer for the ZMR250, specifically designed to fit the Nucleus PDB and mount the ESCs between the bottom plate and the nucleus. 2 variants are available: the variant with separators providing ~36x21x8.5mm of space per ESC
the variant without separators between the ESCs providing ~75x45x8.5mm of continuous space

Flip the design over so the ESC plate is touching your build plate.  
The ESC Plate is supposed to touch on the PDB during assembly, so the ESCs are basically "hanging" from the PDB

comments.text: I found some CAD model of a ZMR250 on tinkercad I think and based the design on that model. It fits my particular frame, but I cannot guarantee that it will fit every ZMR due to production variances and such.

remixed_from.author: wesner0019
remixed_from.title: Updated: Z-axis Anti-backlash 1/4-16 Acme Threaded Modification

description.text:
I designed this to fit the MakerFarm Prusa i3v (tested on the 8 inch) for less backlash. It's pretty much identical to Wesner's except it's made for the springs I had on hand (hence why I supplied the sketchup file) and designed for the stock 5mm rods.
Simple design, just pop an m5 nut onto the threaded rod, then the spring, then another m5 nut and screw it down to your desired length. Then slide the printed part over it and bolt it to the x axis :)

description.text:
Designed to hold a 1/4 inch captive nut and washer, this mount provides an easy way attach your SkyZone/Boscam RC832 FPV video receiver to the top of a standard photographic light stand or tripod at the correct angle.  
You'll need a couple of zip ties, or alternatively some adhesive-backed velcro.
Fits 1/4inch nuts up to 5mm high, washers up to 1.5mm thick. The washer slot should be exactly 20mm in length, and the base 25mm square on your printed version if scale is correct.

title: badBrick - Parallax Continuous Rotation Servo Brick Top Mount.

description.text:
badBrick - Parallax Continuous Rotation Servo Brick Top Mount.  
Fits 1 (one)  Parallax Continuous Rotation Servo in a  8x3x4 Brick.  This mount is intended to hold up a Parallax Continuous Rotation Servo  for prototyping some ideas.  
The brick itself is equal to 4 (3x8) Lego bricks. So it can be "bricked" into a nice support structure to hold it in place.  
A huge help when you are trying to make something and don't want your sensors out and loose.  
This brick was specifically designed to hold the Parallax Continuous Rotation Servo but it may hold other servos as well.

Print parts with Mount feet down. Its designed to reduce edge curling. In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings: Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240 All other defaults are the same. Clip off the feet, file the egdes, and sand smooth for a good snug fit. If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at badbrick.com/catalog

author: megabusa

title: Dual Drive Bowden Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 14-01-16:
New files added for use with MK8 drive gears. Unfortunately I would have had to compromise the design too much to make a version which can do both MK7 and MK8 gears, so theres two slightly different parts with slight changes to the geometry. The smaller diameter MK8 drive gears will give a slightly higher gear ratio, so more force on the filament, however they will also have slightly less grip as there will be less teeth in contact. UPDATE 06-01-16:
Some updates to the V2 extruder frame and pivot arm. All the geometry is the same but there are now better mounting holes, a filament guide above the drive gears, some levers to grab to make it easier to change filament! UPDATE 13-10-15:
I have left the MK1 files there in case anyone wants to remix or modify them, but MK2 is superior in many ways so if your building one for the first time, MK2 should be the one to build. Lots of updates, now using off the shelf MK7 drive gears so you don't need to hob anything (unless you want to), its easier to print, there are bearings on the pivot arm, and the drive gears are now located in between the shaft bearings so you can apply much more clamping force without the arm or frame twisting!

There are many extruder designs out there already, why do we need another one? Well, you might not. If you are running a small printer, with a direct extruder, then this is not for you. If you are running a small printer with a direct drive bowden extruder, then its still probably not for you. This is aimed at BIG printers, with the aim of going FAST. I run a relatively large delta printer, not the largest out there by any means, but large enough to get some pretty large volume prints on the plate. And the problem you soon discover with large prints is that they take AAAGGGEEESSS. My problem is also compounded because I run 3mm filament into a 0.35mm j-head hot end. Not the highest flowing hot end, and a small nozzle to be squeezing plastic out of. The second thing that plagues large bowden extruder printers is retraction. Because my bowden tube is 800mm long, I need a lot of retraction to avoid stringing. Lots of retraction means lots of running back and forward over the same poor piece of filament, which leads to grinding, slipping, and under extrusion. Ideally I would be running about 8mm of retraction, with 3mm filament 8mm is a lot of extrusion out the hot end before I get a fresh piece of filament to grip. I soon established that my primary limiting factor was grip on the filament. To print fast I had to put a lot of spring pressure on the drive roller, which means when you retract back over the same piece of filament it gets destroyed. The fix? More teeth. By gripping the filament from both sides you get twice as many teeth holding it so can use less pressure and get the same grip. With nice sharp hobbed bolts I can make my stepper slip before the filament does, grip is not a problem with this arrangement! The gear ratio is only 1:2.5 which is less than most Wades extruders, but there is a trade off between gear ratio and how big those gears get. With a decent spec motor you should still have plenty of torque (I use a 42BYGHM809). This is now the second version, clearly the first one worked well enough that I decided to keep working on the concept. The second one works even better! I can print faster, retract faster, and have less problems grinding filament with lots of retraction on small models. I would love to see a few more out there and see if they work well for anyone else too. It was intended for use with 3mm filament and a bowden setup. I guess theres no reason you couldn't use it as a direct extruder, but you would need a fairly large printer for it not to look silly (its pretty bulky). If you run 1.75mm filament then you probably dont need it, but I dont know anything about printing with 1.75 filament so feel free to correct me and give it a go! Bear with me, this is a work in progress. Any questions, just post a comment I'll do my best to answer. For anyone who wants to push their extruder to its limits I consider this article to be mandatory reading:
http://www.extrudable.me/2013/04/18/exploring-extrusion-variability-and-limits/ Note that he is using a 0.6 nozzle, so his results may not be directly comparable to your setup. I intend to perform a similar test for my setup, but I haven't had time yet. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AV3KpuHrKA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WPuSdkbF-h0

Some quick notes on printing and assembly: I have yet to see a printer which can print bearing bores accurate enough not to need any clean up. I know mine always come out slightly undersize so I gently take them out with a dremel until I get the correct fit. Dont force your bearing in if the bore is too small, you will either wreck the bearing or split your print. To avoid stressing the print I prefer them slightly loose, you can always put a blob of super glue on if they start creeping out. I now recommend printing the gears solid, 2 shells and 100% infill if your printer will do that nicely. I used to print my gears with 2 shells and 50% infill but the motor gear in particular is under a lot of stress and needs the set screw done up very tight to prevent it working loose. If your gears aren't strong enough the pressure of the set screw will deform the gear. At the very least try and do the motor gear at 100% infill. 0.2mm layer height is fine, but feel free to go for smaller if your printer is up for it. You will want to experiment with what works best and forms the best teeth. My internal bores always come out undersize, so I run a drill through to clean them up. You will need a drill press to do this, if the hole isn't straight the gears will wobble as they turn and everything with try and shift around and bind up as it rotates. I personally find this the hardest part of the process, the gears must be concentric to the shafts or you will lose a lot of power where the gears bind up and dont run true. I grind a small flat on the shafts for the grub screw to locate on. Dont crank the grub screws up too tight or you will push the gears off centre. Do them just tight enough that the gears dont slip on the shaft. The exception is the motor gear, put a big flat on the shaft and do it up as tight as you can, I also put a blob of loctite on the set screw to prevent it working lose. The pivot arm is under quite a bit of stress, print it as strong as you can. I think I did 3 shells and 50% infill from memory. It also requires support due to its wonky shape. Print it with the flat side down on the bed. I slipped some washers either side of the pivot arm when I assembled it to keep it centered, these may or may not be required depending on how accurate your gears are. In theory the herring bone gears do all of the lateral location, but if you have a bit of clearance on the teeth or they aren't very round you can run into trouble. MK1 was a pain to assemble and required lots of pictures, I think MK2 is much more self explanatory, but let me know if you get stuck! The second large gear and the idler gear at the back need to be slid on as a pair. Because there is no adjustment they have to be meshed together and slide on together (yes it is a pain, sorry =P) MK2 BOM: Fasteners (this was only a quick count up, I may have missed something):
2 x M4 x 35 cap screws
4 x M4 washers
7 x M4 nuts
5 x M4 x 10 grub screws
3 x M3 x 12 cap screws (or the appropriate thread for your stepper motor)
3 x M3 washers Other:
8 x MR105DD bearings (5 x 10 x 4)
3 x 5mm shafts - 73mm, 80mm and 85mm lengths
2 x compression springs
2 x MK7 drive gears (ebay ones are rubbish, buy good ones or make your own).
1 x 6mm push fitting with M5 thread (I use this one: http://alfa-tech3d.com/ptfe-tubing/connectors-for-ptfe-tube-all-metal-o-6-mm-with-m5-for-3-mm-filament.html) Someone asked about hobbing the bolts and drive gears so heres some notes: I make my hobbed bolts using a drill press and a hobbing jig. Its a bit of a skill to get it right, but once you know how to do it you are set for life. My hobbing jig is simply a piece of wood with a 10mm hole drilled through it, and two 22mm recesses to take 608 bearings. For 3mm filament I use an M4 tap I start by putting my bolt in the drill press and spinning it up, and using a cutoff disk in a dremel to mark a groove. Once there is a good size groove I put the tap in the drill press and the bolt through the hobbing jig. Line the bolt up with the tap and clamp another piece of wood to the drill press table to use as a guide (this stops the tap pushing the jig sideways and climbing out of the groove). Now just run the drill press nice and slowly and push the bolt against the tap. You need to apply a decent amount of pressure so the tap can bite and cut, but not so much that you snap the tap. Always keep a bit of pressure against your guide so you know everything is sitting in the right spot. A little drop of oil or tapping fluid will help the tap cut cleanly. Every few mins you can stop and check your depth and blow away the chips. For making MK7 drive gears start with a piece of bar 13mm diameter. I hob them till the diameter measures 11.5mm in the groove.

comments.text: Thanks for this design! I made one, but rather than search for mk8 gears with shallow enough groves, I did a mk8 gear, and then a 36tooth 11mm gear on the other side. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01J5ON2Y2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1. I should probably change the gear ratio on this side since the 11mm gear has a larger radius, but seems to work pretty well.

comments.text: Well as long as nothing is slipping your actual extrusion should always match how much you asked for. You can quite easily establish your maximum extrude speed for your setup by printing something like a 20mm calibration cube and just increase your layer height and print speed until you start start seeing under extrusion.

comments.text: Ah, damn. I was worried that might happen. I'm not sure what you can do with those without any tools. Perhaps one of the alternative drive gear designs that use spikes or flat teeth rather than hobbing?

comments.text: Just checked it out.They have custom made drive gears with the correct hob depth (and also gear teeth on the back to drive the two gears). You could definitely hob yourself a set of drive gears that would work, but you may not find anything off the shelf.

comments.text:
Well... I'm a little bummed. Asked at the reprap forums most of them told me that this is unnecessary and whatnot. which is probably true, since a new mk8 drive gear basically fixed all my issues. BUT: more force is always nice and since my current extruder is ungeared and I am now infact get missed steps (Way better than damaged filament!) and I also printed / ordered all of the parts for your extruder, I was still looking for drive gears that would work.

comments.author: JYount

comments.text: M4 nuts and set screws for the gears. I try to avoid M3 bolts unless absolutely necessary, because the nuts spin in the slots unless your tolerances are spot on.
comments.author: JYount

comments.text: Guess what guys, MK2 models are up!!!
comments.author: invent3d

comments.text:
Hi,
I'm in the process of printing this extruder since I like it alot but now I saw your comment on a MKII version in the works. When is it finished? Do many parts differ? I have printed the gears, should I wait for the new files or continue with the existing ones?
comments.author: JBear

comments.text: Sorry, I have been away overseas and didnt get the mk2 parts up before I left. There are no common parts between the two. The main decider will be bearings, you need different sized bearings for mk2, so if you bought bearings for mk1 maybe stick with that. Apart from that I think mk2 is better in many respects, its a complete redesign.
comments.author: JBear

comments.text: I haven't bought the bearings yet and I'm not in a hurry so I'll probably wait for the mk2. While searching for MK7 drive gears I found that there are MK8 drive gears as well. It seems the difference is in the hobbing pattern with other dimensions staying the same so I guess MK8 drive gear would fit your mk2 design.
comments.author: invent3d

comments.text: Either Mk7 or Mk8 is fine, mk8 will give a higher gear ratio but a bit less traction on the fillament. Be careful with cheap drive gears,  i bought some mk7's from ebay and they were junk. I made my own instead, if you can make a hobbed bolt you can make a drive gear with more or less the same procedure.
comments.author: JBear

comments.text:
Very nice design! I too have made a big delta, but with 1.75mm: to be honest, with a RobotDigg drive gear (check them out, they're got amazing grip, very sharp!) and a modified Wades extruder, it pushes very well, but it tends to chew the filament when I try to go too fast (faster than 200-250mm/s just doesn't have time to melt fast enough in the hotend, so the drive gear scraps away during a millisecond!)- how do you adjust the tension on the filament?
On the other hand, I've been considering trying to make a dual-pinch NEMA 14 direct extruder (with these RobotDigg gears!), as I'd MUCH prefer a direct drive extruder, but on the delta (as you've probably found out) a single NEMA extruder cannot be centered, however, I have yet to sort out the tensioning problem - even if I managed to make it with perfect calibration between the gear teeth, eventually I'd need the ability to adjust extruding pressure (when using materials of different hardness, i.e. NinjaFlex, or Woodpile).... any ideas??
Cheers!
comments.author: AndyMy3D

comments.text: Adjusting the tension on two rollers is a tricky problem. Its partly why my design has so many gears. That Robotdigg drive gear looks interesting, I havent seen those before. As you go faster you will always find more limits, whether its drive gear grip, motor torque, heater power, or hot end flow rate. You just have to work out whats limiting you and fix it =) Though I would say once youve hit the max flow rate of your hot end thats probably a sensible place to stop. What extrusion volumetric flow rate can you achieve with your setup (in mm^3/s)?
comments.author: AndyMy3D

comments.text:
How do I calculate that? I've never thought to try that out, all I know is that with a larger nozzle (I've tried from 0.3 to 0.6, which I now keep), you get larger plastic flow, so the extruder has to go faster for a set layer height - as I'm trying got build 30cm parts, I'm trying to get as fast as possible, so a large nozzle gives large layers = shorter build time, but, as mentioned, more problems with too high plastic flow when the hotend can't keep up - now that you ask, it seems clear that there would be a volumetric number that would be the max, and a smaller nozzle (with smaller layers and less plastic coming out the hotend) would be able to print much faster speed, but over all print times would probably be the same... that ties in with my observations, but I never thought to make the calc!
I've actually just changed to a Prometheus from a E3D v5, as the E3D, in addition with the high retraction length on my bowden setup, has a load of sticking PLA problems, that go away for a while adding a drop of oil, but always come back :-( so far the Prometheus hasn't had any problems related to retraction, but I've only had it on a week! It does as well seem to support higher printing speed, so that's nice too!
comments.author: invent3d

comments.text:
Anyone working on improving their extrusion speed should read this as a starting point:
http://www.extrudable.me/2013/04/18/exploring-extrusion-variability-and-limits/
comments.author: AndyMy3D

comments.text: Models are up =D
comments.author: invent3d

comments.text: I like this, have you had any problems with gear backlash?
comments.author: DrJekyll

comments.text: Not that I have noticed. I dont think backlash should be an issue since you only drive in one direction, your retract might be a bit sloppy but you should end up in the same place when you go forward again.
comments.author: DrJekyll

comments.text:
Wow... you read my mind!
I was just thinking of designing something like this. Want to push filament fast thru an E3D Volcano and was also worried about chewing it up.
Can you give some details on how you made the hobbed bolt heads?
Look forward to downloading your files!
comments.author: kentxu

title: MakerBot Filament Spool Holder for shelf mounting

description.text: I loved the original spool holder's design, but have a Cupcake sitting on a little shelf, where there's not much room for things to stick out the sides of the bot. I modified the design to be able to hang off a vertical 20.5mm board (the wall of the shelf) However, it needs to be printed in two parts, because of overhangs. Haven't printed it yet, but will soon!

Print both parts (be sure to center the stl's, they have a tendency to be lower than the platform...), Put bolts through the 6 holes (not sure if all 6 are really needed) and hang your spool!
Also, design files are posted in Inventor 2011 IPT format, I can post in other formats upon request!

Designed to attach to the vertical pole of a standard photographic light stand (or any 15-17mm pole, really), this mounting clip is designed to use a 1/4 inch captive bolt and wingnut for easy adjustment.  
The 50x25mm front face is ideal for some adhesive-backed velcro.

The arm of my mug was broken. So I made a holder for it. The position is not exactly I wan but anyway it seems ok for use. The inside diameter of the holder is 85mm and 81mm (upper and lower side, respectively.) If it happened to fit your needs, welcome to download it.  
By the way, I created this with SketchUp. It is very strange to me that I can't make a real true round circle. Anyone knows how to do it right? Please teach me. Thanks.
I made it with 0.3mm layer, 30% infill, no base, no support.

• left and right clips broke off the original
  • reverse engineered:
  • made clips a bit thicker
  • removed holes near the clips
    • ribbon is really tight which makes it not so easy to re-assamble it.
    to do so:
  • remove top case of printer - or lift it up until you reach to gears of motors
  • remove the gear of one motor - take car not to get ribbon out of place too much
  • fix print head ribbon clip to both ribbon ends
  • put ribbon around gear and with some force push gear back on motor
  • re-assemble printer
  • clip the clip back on to the head
took the original - reverse engineered it - improved a bit - printed with stratasys fdm for more accuracy in full solid

This is a collection of simple geometric cookie cutters, along with the customizer script to generate your own.  
I was frustrated by not being able to find simple geometric cookie cutters the size and dimensions I wanted. I wanted small cutters for a 1 YO with the right wall thickness for my slightly temperamental Thing-O-Matic. I took 15 minutes to write the script. I have uploaded a selection of cutters. Please adjust away and make whatever works for you!

To design your own, open the script in customizer (or download to play with it at home). There are Geometry options and cutter options.  
The geometry options allow you to specify the size (diameter) and the number of sides. There are also options which allow you to skew the cutter by changing the ratio of the X:Y lengths. This allows you to create shapes like ovals, odd triangles, diamonds and rectangles. You will get different effects by rotating the shape before applying the skew.  
The cutter options are where you can adjust the details to work well for your machine. Set the cutter thickness to a width that works for you.  
Enjoy the script and post your creations!

in the style of a Chesley Bonestell 50s style scientific design moon rocket
this thing is far too big to print in one piece - over 200 mm tall! -
(although if anyone wants the original file let me know )
I cut the rocket into 4 sections with several alternate pieces for the second and third sections. all the sections are hollow,(hopefully saving a lot of time and plastic ). section 1 is
designed to accommodate 4-5mm LEDs with hollows leading down one of the wing struts to allow for wiring power.
this is intended to be the first in a series of Bonestell / von Braun style ships. Assuming I don't burn out on the idea first ( this took a good 7 + hours to make-and it's the one that's fairly simple! ) Any comments greatly appreciated please please??

section 1-( 28 mmH x 60mmW )
section 2-(85 mm)-with and without the airlock
section 3-(75 mm)-blank, blank with cargo door,with Windows, with Windows and cargo door
section 4-(24mm)-nosecone same on all print one each of sections 1, 2, 3 and 4 and glue together
remembering to run the wire and LEDs first if you intend to light it
you may need to clean up the holes first to get the LEDs to fit
/// May 12-added a launch 'flames' base which is hollow and about 1 mm thick throughout ///
if you use the section3 with the cargo door you might find it fun to install a floor from a thin piece of plastic stock and make a little cargo room and perhaps a little tiny Crane which is what I'm planning to do when I finally get around to printing this thing.

Typically the kind of thing you see attached to awnings or eves, with a TV antenna attached. see this image: https://www.telcoantennas.com.au/site/sites/default/files/imagecache/product_full/antenna-J-pole-hockey-stick-gutter-fascia-bracket-mount.png The desirable cross-arm would be aluminium 19mm box tube. It's not hard for me to design different mountings to your need - or you can download inventor part file as well. Inventor files attached for the budding modding enthusiast.
More info to come as I print and test them. Currently testing in transparent PLA....
ABS versions to come later. Finally - remember not all printers are equal, not all operators are pro's.
Your results may vary, but my models measure up to spec.

Leadscrews plate and bracket for Makerfarm Pursa printer.
For this upgrade you will need to buy:
  • 2pcs of 5x8mm coupler.
  • 2pcs of 300mm length, 8mm diameter lead-screw with 2mm pitch and 4 starts (this was my specific choice).
  • 2pcs of compatible brass nuts.
    • Notice that the bracket itself won't be enough because the motor centerline need do move a bit forward to mach the bracket centerline! You will also need to make a small change (that i had drafted) at the cofiguration.h file:

You can calculate your own based on this logic. And this is why you should do this upgrade yourself:
http://www.protoparadigm.com/news-updates/accuracy-vs-precision-and-threaded-rod-vs-leadscrews-in-3d-printers/ Of course i will be happy to assist further more.
Please upload a picture of your printing and give me feedbacks if you like.

title: Series I Land Rover SWB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Land Rover entered production in 1948 with what was later termed the Series I. This was launched at the Amsterdam Motor Show. It was originally designed for farm and light industrial use, and had a steel box-section chassis, and an aluminum body. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Rover_Series
http://www.crankandpiston.com/on-the-road/1955-land-rover-series-i-86-the-legend-in-the-uae/ This is roughly based on the original 1959 Moko Lesney Matchbox toy, #12, Land Rover 86 inch wheelbase AKA SWB. A longer wheelbase (107 inches) was also available. http://www.bamca.org/cgi-bin/single.cgi?id=RW12a While I can't duplicate the finish of the original die cast, I can add details like spare tyres for mounting on the bonnet or rear bulkhead. There are two versions of the short-wheelbase body, one with a driver and one without. If you haven't seen "The Gods Must Be Crazy" stop whatever you are doing and find, steal, or download (maybe all three) the movie. Here's a little snippet: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fxCJL6GGsdE UPDATE 4/6/13 I have uploaded a double-sized version of the driverless Series I SWB, in several files. It is twice the size of the original Matchbox model, with upgraded Non-Directional-Tread (NDT) on the tires, a dubious vanity on my part. Some dimensions have been altered to better reflect a generic 86 inch wheelbase Series I - They came in a variety of subtly different styles. The bigger wheels necessitates bigger axles and retainers (hubs), included in the new plates. The fit is tight; you might want to drill out the wheels a bit. Also, all the embellishments precipitated some non-manifoldness - which I easily solved using the Netfabb cloud fixing tool - you can too: http://www.netfabb.com/news.php
Jambo!

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

Some assembly required.  I used 3 mm filament as axles, glued in place and trimmed flush with the side of the body (see picture).  Careful, don't scratch the Birmabrite! The tyres should be chased with an 1/8-inch drill bit prior to fitting to the axles, the end of the filament "peened" by melting with a hot implement. I used a screw with a suitable concavity in the end of the threaded bit.  Super glue seems to work very well with ABS, and I used it to fix the spare tyres to the bonnet or the rear bulkhead (early Land Rovers NEVER carried spares on the quarter panel or tailgate like a Jeep).  The windscreen can be fixed vertically or horizontally (or omitted), as per your mood (should have a jaunty rake). I hope to eventually model a hardtop for winter or livery use - removable of course.  
Small version printed with 50% infill, larger version with 25%  
NDT tyres updated 5-9-13 to fix symmetry problem.  
5-20-13  If you have problems getting the large version of the tyres and axles to print, Thingiversian jeromemaurey has corrected the tyre plate here: ://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91441  Thanks!  
Fix incorporated into double-sized plates.  Thanks again!

title: Chevy SB Receiverbox for Axial Wraith

description.text:
Now you can change your stock receiverbox of your Axial Wraith with this cool Chevy SB V8 receiverbox. It can hold a RC-Receiver with the max. dimensions of 55mm x 26mm x 16mm. I´ve separated the "bolt on" parts of the engine. That gives you the ability to print the engine parts in different colors. After printing the parts can be glued together. Some parts are real tricky to print such as Kabelstrang.stl, Einspritzleiste.stl. I´ve provided a holding structure for these parts (you have to combine it with the support structure of your slicing software). The part Zuendkabel.stl is impossible to print (on my Ultimaker 2). You can print the parts of any material of your choice (I prefer PLA). I used flexible PLA for the serpentine belt (Rippenriemen.stl) You need 2 pieces of the part "Ventildeckel.stl" (the Valvecovers). To mount the Engine Model on your Wraith, you have to delete the existing RC-Box, the upper and lower crossmember and the plastic plug (where you can adjust the slipper spring). Then pack your receiver in the engine block and screw on the Transmission bellhousing (screws: 3x12mm with thread for plastic). After that, place the engine into engine compartment of your Wraith and screw it on with the bolts of the lower crossmember. Reinstall the upper crossmember. That´s all!! If you want to equip your receiverbox with a Blower or carburetor or add a pair of realistic looking headers, visit my homepage!!!
The last two pictures shows some Upgrades for the Receiverbox. They are not a part of this database, but you can get these parts on my homepage:
https://www.printable-3d-models.com/de/3d-druckvorlagen/3D-druckbares-rc-zubehoer/upgradekits-fuer-die-chevy-smallblock-receiverbox/ Have Fun with this Kit!!!!

title: Sink Drain -print flat, form with hot water

description.text:
The sink drain printed on Geek Pride Day one year back has served us well -but why not make one less deep, and with at faster process: printing it flat, and then forming a dent after heating in hot, near boiling, water (material: PLA).
A very quick and smooth print, as opposed to printing holes in an overhang. And the forming itself was easy! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jewRudI3rpQ The model for the drain is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:150307, with parameter for height set (DipDepth) to zero.
The hot water forming is inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:403001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=150307

print flat
boil a little water, take kettle off heat source
soak the flat drain for a few seconds (3-4 is enough)
put on a metal ring, press down with a round object
-There! Customizer, Using the following options: thick = 2
h_r_pitch = 4
dipdepth = 0
i_rad = 20
o_rad = 31
h_c_pitch = 4
h_rad = 1.5

title: Han Solo In Carbonate Iphone 6 Case for Ninja Flex

description.text:
Took a very nice case for the Iphone 6 from ttturner68 on here and modified it with another Iphone 6 Hard case of Han Solo in Carbonite. This iconic scene can now be shrunk down to phone size and printed on your printer.   
This design is for use with Ninja Flex Semi-Flex. It will not fit around your phone if you don't use a flexible filament. Since Ninja Flex can not be sanded I made my own Support structure for the part. It is a hair smaller then the actual case. This way it will not stick to bad to the part itself.  
Feel free to download it and see how it works!

title: Nintendo NES Cartridge Dust Cover Sleeve

description.text:
This is the exact size and shape of the original NES (Nintendo Entertainment System) cartridge dust covers.  The walls are sized to print 2 shells thick on a Replicator 2.  At 0.2mm layer height this takes ~2 hours 15 minutes to print.  
NOTE: If you have trouble with your replicator creating a weak seam at the "zipper" try setting your "retractDistance" to "1.1".  
In addition to an STL, I included an X3G file for the Replicator 2.

title: generator project, big gear and little gear

description.text: i am building a small generator. the big gear can mount on a water wheel or wind mill, whatever. the little gear is mounted on a small generator. i gave you the blender files which you can modify the gears. the little gear can easily just change the center hole. the big gear is made to screw or bolt to a bigger drive unit, then drive the little wheel to spin a small generator faster. small generator could be a DC motor or other perminant magnet gen. 36.95mm is the center to center of the gears, with my printer. gives a free spin with no binding. it is the same center to center as my open sourced 3D printed bobbin winder, and the same gear pattern. the original gears are from a rep rap filament drive

description.text: It is a rack that holds whatever you want to hang from it.  Since it is in the shape of a dog bone, I'd suggest using it for leashes or collars.

Print both the mount and the rack.  The mount has clearance for two #10 wood screws that I secured to a wall stud.  The mount uses a tapered dovetail that will only orient properly one way, so make sure you mount it correctly.  If you mount it upside down, just remove the screws and flip it around.  Once the mount is attached to the wall, slide the rack onto it and you're ready to start hanging stuff.  It's about 6-3/8" x 2-5/8".

This thing is a stand for the NES (Nintendo Entertainment System).  It is sized to allow the Wii U to fit perfectly underneath, saving shelf space.  The stand features cutouts for the NES' feet for a secure fit.  
This design is 150mm deep so it just fits on a Replicator 2 platform.   
Prints in ~4 hours 30 minutes with a layer height of 0.2mm and infill of 10%.  
I suggest sticking some rubber feet to the bottom of the legs to prevent the stand from sliding around. (available at your local hardware store)

The room where we have the Replicator Desktop 5th generation is drafty. So I needed a way to stop the draft. In the cellar i found a plastic sheet 1mm thick from an old canvas.

Print:
1 "handle"
6 "corner"
6 "side" Glue the corners and sides to Replicator. Drill two hole in the front plastic sheet so it fits with the handle. Update 24 June 2015: I made a top cover as well. Print:
3 "35 corner"
2 "35 foot"
4 "90 corner"
4 "45 corner" Trying a new door with hinges, found: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:381175
And made an modified version for gluing on to the plastic sheet. I will try to use neodyne magnet to act as a lock for the door. Enjoy a draft-free build plate.

This is a remix of rmcniff http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222667 extruder arm upgrade. This thing gives you the ability to use the m4 shoulder screws for the bearing instead of the m4 flat head or the printed peg version. You can use the original cover piece provided by the thing linked above. Note: you may need to drill out the bearing through hole in the cover piece to fit the shoulder screw through.
